author: PTI
title: Good Friday 2024: PM Narendra Modi Recalls Profound Sacrifice of Jesus Christ on Good Friday, Says â€˜It Teaches People Compassion and Forgivenessâ€™ | ðŸ™ðŸ» LatestLY
text: New Delhi, March 29: Prime Minister Narendra Modi remembered the "profound sacrifice" of Jesus Christ on Good Friday, saying it teaches people compassion and forgiveness. Good Friday 2024 Wishes: PM Narendra Modi, Mamata Banerjee and Other Leaders Extend Greetings to Christians on the Day That Marks the Crucifixion of Jesus Christ He said on X, "Today, on Good Friday, we remember the profound sacrifice of Jesus Christ. May everyone find strength in the lessons of compassion and forgiveness it teaches us." Good Friday 2024: Christians Mark the Crucifixion of Jesus Christ With Solemn Processions and Prayers in Kerala (Watch Video) PM Modi Recalls Profound Sacrifice of Jesus Christ on Good Friday Today, on Good Friday, we remember the profound sacrifice of Jesus Christ. May everyone find strength in the lessons of compassion and forgiveness it teaches us. â€” Narendra Modi (@narendramodi) March 29, 2024 Christians across the world observe Good Friday to commemorate the crucifixion of Christ.

author: @badgerfootball
title: Wisconsin football earns AFCA Academic Achievement Award
text: Football December 05, 2024 Wisconsin football earns AFCA Academic Achievement Award Football matched the program's highest-ever graduation success rate this year Football December 05, 2024 Wisconsin football earns AFCA Academic Achievement Award Football matched the program's highest-ever graduation success rate this year MADISON, Wis. â€“ For the first time ever, Wisconsin football has been awarded the American Football Coaches Association's (AFCA) 2024 Academic Achievement Award, as announced by the Memphis Touchdown Club on Thursday. Wisconsin earned the award after posting a 91% graduation success rate in 2024, matching the program's highest mark ever. Wisconsin joins Air Force, Clemson, Liberty, Notre Dame, Virginia and Wake Forest in receiving the 2024 Academic Achievement Award. Head coaches of the winning schools will be honored during the 2025 AFCA Convention in Charlotte, N.C., on Sunday, Jan. 12. Wisconsin's roster featured 13 players who had earned their degrees prior to the beginning of the 2024 season. 15 Badgers are on track to graduate this month with degrees from the University of Wisconsin. This year's award marks the 13th time the NCAA's Graduation Success Rate (GSR) one-year formula has been used to select the winner. The GSR is based on a six-year graduation window for student-athletes and holds institutions accountable for transfer students, unlike the federal graduation rate. The GSR also accounts for midyear enrollees and non-scholarship students at schools that do not offer athletics aid. Under GSR calculation, institutions are not penalized for outgoing transfer students who leave in good academic standing. These outgoing transfers are passed to the receiving institution's GSR cohort. The Academic Achievement Award was established by the College Football Association in 1981. The award recognized the CFA-member Football Bowl Subdivision institution with the highest graduation rate among members of its football team. When the CFA disbanded in 1997, the AFCA stepped in to present the award. Print Friendly Version

author: TV5MONDE
title: Boeing nie officiellement toute violation d'un accord avec la justice sur deux crashes
text:
[Back to top](#skip-link)
Des Boeing 737 MAX clouÃ©s au sol aprÃ¨s deux crashes en 2018 et en 2019, le 18 novembre 2020 Ã  Seattle
Le constructeur aÃ©ronautique Boeing a officiellement contestÃ© les conclusions du ministÃ¨re amÃ©ricain de la Justice, qui a prÃ©venu mi-mai d'un risque de poursuites pÃ©nales pour non-respect d'un accord conclu aprÃ¨s deux crashes ayant fait 346 morts.
L'avionneur devait rÃ©pondre au plus tard jeudi. Ce qui a Ã©tÃ© fait, a indiquÃ© Ã  l'AFP une source proche du dossier, sans autre dÃ©tail.
L'agence Bloomberg a rapportÃ© que Boeing avait adressÃ© sa rÃ©ponse mercredi, niant toute violation. ContactÃ© par l'AFP mercredi, Boeing avait renvoyÃ© Ã  ses dÃ©clarations du 14 mai: "Nous estimons avoir honorÃ© les conditions de cet accord".
Le constructeur a refusÃ© de commenter ses communications avec le ministÃ¨re de la Justice (DOJ), prÃ©cisant "continuer de dialoguer en toute transparence" avec lui. Le ministÃ¨re n'a pas souhaitÃ© commenter non plus.
Dans un courrier adressÃ© le 14 mai au juge d'un tribunal fÃ©dÃ©ral texan, le ministÃ¨re a estimÃ© que Boeing n'avait "pas respectÃ© ses obligations" prÃ©vues dans l'accord dit de poursuite diffÃ©rÃ©e (DPA) signÃ© le 7 janvier 2021 et liÃ© aux crashes de deux 737 MAX 8 en 2018 et 2019 -dus Ã  un problÃ¨me de conception.
AccusÃ© de fraude dans le processus de certification du 737 MAX -son avion vedette-, Boeing avait acceptÃ© de payer 2,5 milliards de dollars et s'Ã©tait engagÃ©, entre autres, Ã  renforcer son programme de conformitÃ©.
Mais l'avionneur multiplie, surtout depuis dÃ©but 2023, les problÃ¨mes de production et de contrÃ´le qualitÃ©.
Il est dÃ©sormais cernÃ© de toutes parts depuis l'incident en vol sur un 737 MAX 9 d'Alaska Airlines le 5 janvier, dont une porte-bouchon -opercule condamnant une issue de secours redondante- s'est dÃ©tachÃ©e.
L'affaire de trop, qui a dÃ©clenchÃ© audits et enquÃªtes des rÃ©gulateurs, de la justice, de commissions parlementaires. Ces travaux ont identifiÃ© des problÃ¨mes de non-conformitÃ© dans la production et des lacunes du contrÃ´le qualitÃ©.
Trois des quatre familles d'avions commerciaux actuellement fabriquÃ©s par Boeing sont visÃ©s par des enquÃªtes de la FAA pour des problÃ¨mes de qualitÃ©: le 737, le 777 et le 787 Dreamliner.
Le groupe a annoncÃ© jeudi matin un nouveau souci repÃ©rÃ© sur des Dreamliner en attente de livraison: des fixations internes au fuselage mal serrÃ©es. "La flotte en service peut continuer Ã  opÃ©rer en toute sÃ©curitÃ©", a-t-il assurÃ©.
Le Boeing 737 MAX 9 d'Alaska Airlines dont une porte condamnÃ©e s'est dÃ©tachÃ©e en vol, Ã  l'aÃ©roport de Portland, le 23 janvier 2024 dans l'Oregon
La sÃ©curitÃ© des avions de Boeing a quasiment monopolisÃ© l'audition pendant prÃ¨s de deux heures jeudi matin de Mike Whitaker, patron du rÃ©gulateur de l'aviation civile (FAA), devant la Commission sÃ©natoriale sur le Commerce et le Transport au sujet de la supervision du secteur aÃ©rien.
"Ces problÃ¨mes sont vraiment contrariants", a relevÃ© Maria Cantwell, prÃ©sidente dÃ©mocrate de la Commission, dÃ©plorant une "impression de dÃ©jÃ  vu".
M. Whitaker, en poste depuis octobre 2023, a assurÃ© que des mesures avaient Ã©taient prises immÃ©diatement aprÃ¨s l'incident du 5 janvier, dont le plafonnement de la production du 737 MAX tant que la qualitÃ© ne serait pas retrouvÃ©e.
Le constructeur a dÃ» aussi Ã©laborer, en collaboration avec la FAA, un plan complet pour y parvenir.
Le rÃ©gulateur a aussi dÃ©ployÃ©, pour la premiÃ¨re fois, des inspecteurs parmi les chaÃ®nes de montage de Boeing et de Spirit AeroSystems, qui le fournit notamment en fuselages. Son objectif est d'en dissÃ©miner 55 mais la pÃ©nurie de personnel qualifiÃ© complique le recrutement, a indiquÃ© M. Whitaker.
Le site du crash d'un Boeing 737 MAX 8 d'Ethiopian Airways, prÃ¨s de Bishoftun, le 16 mars 2019 en Ethiopie
L'accord de 2021 prÃ©voyait l'expiration de la surveillance de Boeing aprÃ¨s trois ans. Soit le 7 janvier 2024. Le ministÃ¨re disposait ensuite de six mois pour se positionner puis dÃ©cider d'engager ou non des poursuites.
Les familles de victimes des deux accidents les rÃ©clament depuis le tout dÃ©but, et encore plus depuis la rÃ©cente sÃ©rie de dÃ©boires.
ReÃ§ues le 31 mai au ministÃ¨re Ã  Washington, elles ont fait part de leurs "grandes craintes" qu'il opte pour un accord de plaider-coupable avec Boeing, selon un communiquÃ© de leurs avocats.
"Une simple transaction Ã  l'amiable sans sanction ne remplirait pas" la "mission" du ministÃ¨re "de rendre justice au grand public", ont-ils prÃ©venu, rÃ©clamant l'ouverture d'un procÃ¨s dans les 70 jours lÃ©gaux suivant le 7 juillet.
Le ministÃ¨re s'est engagÃ© en mai Ã  communiquer sa dÃ©cision au tribunal texan au plus tard Ã  cette date-lÃ .
Dave Calhoun, patron de l'avionneur amÃ©ricain Boeing, le 24 janvier 2024 Ã  Washington
Prochain passage difficile pour le groupe: l'audition trÃ¨s attendue de son patron Dave Calhoun le 18 juin par une commission d'enquÃªte sÃ©natoriale, devant laquelle quatre lanceurs d'alerte ont tÃ©moignÃ© mi-avril.
NommÃ© directeur gÃ©nÃ©ral dÃ©but 2020 pour rÃ©tablir la situation aprÃ¨s les crashes, M. Calhoun a Ã©tÃ© emportÃ© par la crise actuelle et doit quitter son poste d'ici la fin de l'annÃ©e.

author: Pierra Willix
title: â€˜Iâ€™m the real Mr Bates â€“ my battle against the Post Office isnâ€™t over yetâ€™
text: When subpostmaster Alan Bates was accused of theft by his employers, he refused to back down. In 1998, he took over ownership of the local Post Office in Craig-y-Don, north [Wales](https://metro.co.uk/tag/wales/?ico=auto_link_entertainment_P2_LNK1), but two years later the business started struggling. At least that is what Alan was told. His experience, which turned out to be part of [one of the biggest miscarriages of justice in UK history](https://metro.co.uk/2022/02/15/what-was-the-post-office-horizon-scandal-16110574/), is the [ centre of the new four-part ITV drama series](https://metro.co.uk/2023/09/25/the-long-shadow-toby-jones-made-me-cry-playing-my-dad-dcs-dennis-hoban-19542389/?ico=mosaic_tag) Mr Bates vs The Post Office, starring [Toby Jones as Bates alongside Will Mellor, Katherine Kelly and Julie Hesmondhalgh](https://metro.co.uk/tag/toby-jones/). Soon after Alan started working for the company, the Post Office rolled out the Horizon computer system, supplied by Fujitsu, and suddenly unexplained losses started appearing in his accounts. Although his contract [said he was responsible ](https://metro.co.uk/2023/09/18/post-office-workers-wrongful-conviction-false-accounting-compensation-offered-19518576/)for having to pay the money, Alan refused and demanded the computer evidence to prove the cause of the losses. In 2003 his contract was terminated. Determined to prove he wasnâ€™t at fault, over the following years he started tracking down other subpostmasters and subpostmistresses and despite each being told that they were the only ones experiencing these problems with Horizon, they were far from it. Thousands were being affected by the faulty system. As others faced the same horrors as Alan, the Post Office spent nearly 20 years taking 700 employees to court for theft, false accounting and fraud. Some went to prison following convictions, many others were financially ruined and more than 60 died without seeing justice or compensation. At least four took their own lives. Set to air after the final episode of the drama series is the documentary, Mr Bates vs The Post Office: The Real Story, which pieces together the impact of these appalling events, with those affected speaking about what they experienced. In it, Alan explains how he was â€˜never accepting of the figure Horizon had thrown up each weekâ€™. â€˜I wasnâ€™t prepared to do that. They then said I had to do it or else, but I refused until I had access to the system and eventually, they terminated my contract without giving me any reason and that was it,â€™ he said. He added: â€˜They walked off with my life savings and decided to give my post office to someone else.â€™ Many others faced financial ruin too, with Jo Hamilton from South Warnborough being charged with theft. While she ended up accepting a plea deal and pleaded guilty to false accounting, convinced she had been accidentally doing something wrong, she was then made liable for repaying Â£36,000. Jo, along with the help of her supportive community, helped pay it off, however, she has now accepted she wonâ€™t be able to retire for years to come and is working as a cleaner to make ends meet. After Alan and his partner, Suzanne Sercombe lost Â£65,000 in the process of giving up their business, they became determined to seek justice. It was in 2009 that the first meeting of thirty postmasters took place in Fenny Compton, Warwickshire where they shared their stories. Eventually, Alan and five others from the JFSA (Justice For Subpostmasters Alliance) took the Post Office to court on behalf of 555 claimants. A decade after that original meeting, it was ruled the missing money was the fault of computer errors and the Post Office was ordered to pay Â£58million in compensation for the false prosecutions. Judge Fraser described the Post Office denials about Horizon issues as â€˜institutional obstinacyâ€™. But after their legal costs were paid, the group were left with only Â£12million, which totalled to around Â£20,000 each, far less than some had lost. By 2020, the government had initiated an independent inquiry, which was then converted to a public one the following year, looking into whether the Post Office and software supplier Fujitsu knew about the faults in the IT system. It was intended to be completed a few months ago but is still ongoing. In the documentary, Alan makes it clear heâ€™s not ready to stop and will continue to offer a voice to the people impacted by the scandal until they receive their full compensation. This year he also turned down an OBE, citing the fact he didnâ€™t want to accept the honour whilst former Post Office boss Paula Vennells still had her CBE, which she was awarded in 2019. â€˜The people who should be held to account are the people who have had a very cooshtie lifestyle on vast quantities of money whilst theyâ€™ve made hundreds, if not thousands, of individuals suffer whilst knowing the real truth of whatâ€™s been going on and denying it,â€™ Alan says. â€˜Those are the people who should be held responsible.â€™ Mr Bates vs the Post Office is airing across four nights from January 1 at 9pm on ITV1. Also airing on January 4 is Mr Bates vs the Post Office: The Real Story at 10.45pmon ITV1. Got a story? If youâ€™ve got a celebrity story, video or pictures get in touch with the [Metro.co.uk](https://metro.co.uk) entertainment team by emailing us celebtips@metro.co.uk, calling 020 3615 2145 or by visiting our [Submit Stuff](https://metro.co.uk/submit-stuff/) page â€“ weâ€™d love to hear from you. MORE : [The maddest TV moments of 2023 will absolutely blow your mind](https://metro.co.uk/2023/12/26/maddest-tv-moments-2023-ranked-20027577/?ico=more_text_links) MORE : [The big TV quiz of the year](https://metro.co.uk/2023/12/23/big-tv-quiz-year-strictly-happy-valley-20004436/?ico=more_text_links)

author: Staff Reporter
title: Cristiano Ronaldoâ€™s scoring record as Portugal star scores 900th career goal - Limerick Live
text: Cristiano Ronaldo has scored the 900th goal of his illustrious career after netting Portugalâ€™s second during their Nations League clash with Croatia on Thursday night. Here, the PA news agency looks at the 39-year-oldâ€™s scoring record for club and country. Appearances: 31 Goals: 5 The future Portugal star played just one senior season in his homeland, demonstrating his potential with a handful of goals while only turning 18 late in the campaign. Appearances: 346 Goals: 145 That early promise earned him a move to Old Trafford, where he flourished first as a flying winger before adding regular goals to his game. He hit double figures for the first time in 2005-06 before three successive seasons of 20-plus goals, peaking with 31 in the Premier League and 42 in all competitions in 2007-08. His first spell brought a total of 118 goals in 293 games to persuade Real Madrid to part with a then-world record 94 million euros (Â£80million). A markedly less successful second spell in Manchester from 2021 to 2023 produced 27 goals in 54 games before an acrimonious end. Appearances: 438 Goals: 450 It was at Real from 2009 to 2018 that Ronaldo grew into the feared central striker he has become, as his rivalry with then-Barcelona star Lionel Messi saw both achieve scarcely believable scoring rates. Ronaldo had six straight seasons with over 50 goals in all competitions from 2010-11, scoring a goal a game or better in all but the first of those and astonishingly maintaining such a record over his nine-year spell as a whole. His best season brought him 61 goals in 54 games in 2014-15, surpassing his 60 in 55 in 2011-12. He beat Raulâ€™s club records of 228 league goals and 323 in all competitions, became the Champions Leagueâ€™s record scorer â€“ setting the single season record with 17 in 2013-14 â€“ and reached 500 career goals for club and country. By the time he left Spain, his 311 LaLiga goals ranked second only to Messi. Ronaldo won two league titles and three Pichichi trophies as LaLigaâ€™s top scorer, with four Champions Leagues and four Ballons dâ€™Or to take his personal total to five of each. Appearances: 134 Goals: 101 While not matching the extraordinary heights of his time in Spain, Ronaldo remained prolific in his three years with Juve and helped them to two league titles and a Coppa Italia. He scored 28 goals in his debut season then 37 and 36, bringing up his century in his penultimate Serie A appearance. He was named Serie A footballer of the year for 2019 and 2020 and won an Outstanding Career Achievement honour at FIFAâ€™s 2021 The Best awards. Appearances: 74 Goals: 68 A move to Saudi Arabia after his falling-out with United was viewed as a kind of footballing semi-retirement â€“ and was followed by Messi decamping to Major League Soccer in the United States â€“ but the goals have continued to flow. Ronaldo scored 14 in 16 Saudi Pro League games in his debut season then 35 in 31, and is quickly back up and running this term. Appearances: 213 Goals: 131 His countryâ€™s talisman since Luis Figoâ€™s retirement following the 2006 World Cup, Ronaldo has rewritten the record books. Soaring past Ali Daeiâ€™s record of 108 goals in menâ€™s internationals, Ronaldo took 114 caps to reach 50 goals but has 81 in 89 games since. He helped his side win the European Championship in 2016 and is the competitionâ€™s record scorer, both with 14 goals at the finals and 55 including qualifiers. His appearance total and his feats of scoring at five different World Cups and 10 consecutive World Cups and Euros combined are also records. Keep up with the latest news from Donegal with our daily newsletter featuring the most important stories of the day delivered to your inbox every evening at 5pm.

author: Ananya Panchal
title: Selena Gomez Teases New Music After Being Seen in the Studio With FiancÃ© Benny Blanco
text:
Selena Gomez Teases Sheâ€™s Working on New Music After Being Seen in the Studio With Benny Blanco
Selena Gomez is fueling fansâ€™ anticipation for new music with a subtle yet tantalizing tease. On Wednesday, Jan. 22, the 32-year-old took to Instagram Stories to share a video from what appeared to be her home recording studio. Donning oversized headphones, Gomez began the clip with a close-up of her face before dramatically panning to a computer monitor, strategically covered by a big red heart emoji. As she turned the camera back to herself, Gomezâ€™s widened eyes and glowing excitement suggested something big is brewing.
In the background, eagle-eyed viewers caught sight of large studio speakers and a sleek keyboard, hinting at serious creative work underway. And this would align perfectly with a recent TikTok of producer and Gomezâ€™s new fiancÃ© Benny Blanco.
The 36-year-old offered fans another glimpse into the coupleâ€™s studio sessions. He replied to a fan commentâ€”â€œBenny please make some new songs for our queenâ€â€”with a video on Jan. 17 ahead of the anticipated (yet short-lived) TikTok ban. In the clip, Blanco opened the door to a room, revealing the Disney Channel alum adjusting a microphone. Beaming, she greeted him with a playful â€œHi.â€ Watch the TikTok here.
The two, who announced their engagement in December 2024 after a little more than a year of dating but several years of friendship, have a history of crafting hits together, including â€œSame Old Loveâ€ and â€œKill Em With Kindnessâ€ from Gomezâ€™s Revival album, as well as last yearâ€™s chart-topper, â€œSingle Soon.â€
Gomez had previously revealed she was nearing the end of her music career, focusing her energy on acting, where she felt she had only begun to scratch the surface of her potential. However, in a recent interview on Radio Andyâ€™s The Jess Cagle Show with Julia Cunningham, Gomez opened up about how her recent acting projects have reinvigorated her passion for music. Her roles in the award-winning Netflix film Emilia PÃ©rez and the Hulu series Only Murders in the Building have sparked further creativity.
â€œMore than anything, Iâ€™ve never felt so inspired. The work Iâ€™m doing now is everything Iâ€™ve worked hard to do, and Iâ€™m so proud and so fulfilled,â€ Gomez said. â€œIâ€™m still, you know, making my way as I go, but I really am extremely lucky, and I think music is gonna be in my life forever in whatever shape or form â€¦ I think it has truly inspired me, this whole experience.â€
topics: Arts, Culture and Entertainment->arts and entertainment

author: Hayley Taylor
title: Fears for egg shortage as new bird flu case rips though third Victorian poultry farm
text:
Fears for egg shortage as new bird flu case rips though third Victorian poultry farm
A third bird flu case has been detected on a Euroa poultry farm near to where the last two devastating outbreaks occurred in the Victoriaâ€™s north this month, Agriculture Victoria said on Thursday.
The latest H7N8 avian influenza case occurred within a â€œrestricted areaâ€ and was â€œnot unexpected,â€ Victoriaâ€™s acting chief veterinary officer Dr Cameron Bell said.
WATCH THE VIDEO ABOVE: Bird flu outbreak spreads.
Sign up to The Nightly's newsletters.
Get the first look at the digital newspaper, curated daily stories and breaking headlines delivered to your inbox.
By continuing you agree to ourTermsand
Privacy Policy.
With the â€œhumane destructionâ€ of birds now completed at the first two sites infected this month, Agriculture Victoria said: â€œWork will start at the new property soon.â€
The first of the latest H7N8 cases came just days after an eradication announcement was made by Agriculture Minister Julie Collins, and the unfortunate reversal of that position has reignited fears for a continued egg shortage.
As buying limits remain in Aussie supermarkets, Dr Bell thanked reassured Victorians that supermarket eggs and poultry products are still safe to eat.
At the time of the eradication announcement, more than 1.8 million birds had been killed in a quest to rid the nation of the disease after Victoria, New South Wales and the ACT experienced outbreaks.
But the strain which triggered the 2024 egg shortage impacting shelves today is different to the one now impacting the Euroa farms, the Australian Government said diagnostic testing at CSIROâ€™s Australian Centre for Disease Preparedness in Geelong confirmed.
It is also different than the H5 strain, which is currently plaguing every continent except Australia.
The latest case, announced on Thursday, occurred within in a quarantined control area, which covers any producers within a 5km radius of infected properties.
â€œThis is part of a larger control area in Strathbogie Shire, east of the Goulburn Valley Fwy,â€ Agriculture Victoria said.
â€œThe goal is to prevent movements that could spread the virus.â€
Those in Euroa, Violet Town, Longwood, Ruffy, Avenel, and Strathbogie, are all required to follow the specific rules which characterise the control zone, including a housing requirement for properties with 50 or more birds.
â€œIf you are in the control or restricted areas, you cannot move birds, products (including eggs and manure) or equipment into, out of, or within the area without permit,â€ Bell said.
â€œThis includes selling or giving away eggs from your poultry â€” these must not leave your property.â€
Bell thanked the impacted properties for their cooperation and stressed that â€œa strong biosecurity system relies on everyone playing their part.â€
